dict.string:
Notes from the book on R [cliff notes if you will] All the notes in the Cliff-notes section are written verbatim from the Learn R in a Day book- DO NOT USE in any of your written piece that are submitted for class. This is extra information for practice only. Functions in R and their Mathematical Function: Functions are used frequently in R - that also allows R to be able to interpret calculations dynamically (ie. in this case, from within the function command itself) Function in R
Mathematical Function +
Addition -
Subtraction *
Multiplication /
Division sqrt(x)
Square-Root of x x^y
X to the power of y exp(x)
Exponential of x log(x,e)
Natural log of x to the base e factorial(x)
Factorial of x cos(x)
Cosine of x (in radians) sin(x)
Sine of x (in radians) tan(x)
Tangent of x (in radians) abs(x)
Absolute value of x rowMeans(x)
Row means of data frame x colSum(x)
Column sums of data frame x rowSums(x)
Row sums of data frame x Concatenation and Arrays - Concatenation (the process of combining, linking, or joining) numeric or character values is a feature in R. This is achieved by using the c() function. You can create an array by joining the numbers with comas : > f <- c(1,2,3,4,5)
